title: AbstractRetryingPeerTask | No peers available, waiting for peers
body:
## tl;dr
Besu 21.10.9 up-and-running on a fully up-to-date Ubuntu 20.04 Core-i5 4-core/8-thread, 16 GB of RAM, SATA SSD 1 TB  PC. Networking seems OK. Still, I get `AbstractRetryingPeerTask | No peers available, waiting for peers`

## background

Hello, I'm the author of the guide [Guida Ethereum su Ubuntu: come configurare un nodo con Besu partendo da zero (con storage Bonsai)](https://turbolab.it/criptovalute-bitcoin-ethereum-litecoin-4904/guida-ethereum-ubuntu-come-configurare-nodo-besu-partendo-zero-storage-bonsai-3490) - it's in italian, but you can [read it autotranslated here](https://turbolab-it.translate.goog/criptovalute-bitcoin-ethereum-litecoin-4904/guida-ethereum-ubuntu-come-configurare-nodo-besu-partendo-zero-storage-bonsai-3490?_x_tr_sl=it&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en-US&_x_tr_pto=wapp)

My procedure basically looks like this:

* download besu
* setup a user account
* run besu with this service: https://github.com/TurboLabIt/ethereum-autostaker/blob/main/config/besu/mainnet.service.txt

The relevant part of the service is this:

````
WorkingDirectory=/var/lib/besu
Environment="ClientIP=$(dig @resolver4.opendns.com myip.opendns.com +short)"
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c '/usr/local/besu/bin/besu --network=mainnet --data-path=/var/lib/besu --color-enabled=false --Xdata-storage-format=BONSAI --rpc-http-enabled=true --rpc-ws-enabled=true --nat-method=none --p2p-host=${ClientIP}'
````

Yes, I'm using BONSAI. Yes, I understand "it's experimental", but it's also one of the coolest feature of Besu.

I've a residential ADSL line, with a NATing router. Since I don't use UPnP (because it's an abomination), I resolve my current IP address and then pass it to Besu at startup. I already fwd the 30303 port from my router to my PC, and Besu is actually listening and responding to external connections.

About the error `AbstractRetryingPeerTask | No peers available, waiting for peers: 12` it is somewhat misleading since it actually means that there are 12 peers connected, but none of them is useful for that particualr pending request.
